segments.text: Time, 152, Washington, D.C., Office of the Oceanography.
Admiral Snyder, would you explain to us how you first developed an interest in the sea?
What drew you towards the oceans themselves?
Well, do you mean towards oceanography or towards the Navy?
Towards the oceans.
What made you decide to be a career naval man?
Well, my parents, my father was a Methodist minister, and he was the fifth generation Methodist minister, and I didn't want to go into the ministry, and
For some weird reason, as a kid grows up, he wants to be a fireman.
I wanted to be a Navy man.
So when I was five years old, Senator Gerald P. Nye, who was one of these Republican isolationists who stayed forever in North Dakota, appointed me to the United States Naval Academy for 1945.
Enter in the year, I'm sorry, enter in the year 1942.
And this was circa 1930 that he appointed me.
I worked towards that.
We built a retirement home outside.
My father built a retirement home outside of Annapolis.
I went in one year earlier than the senator had appointed me under a civil service competitive and always wanted to be in the Navy.
I certainly never regretted a day of not having made that decision.
Why did Gerald Nye appoint you 12 years in advance?
In North Dakota, they didn't even know about the Navy.
They always knew West Point and the senatorials.
Each senator had two seats in both West Point and the Naval Academy before World War II and two from each of the
Each of the congressmen had two.
And the appointments to the Naval Academy went begging.
The appointments to West Point were very competitive.
And my father was the district superintendent.

And I guess that in those days, before World War II, almost all, about 75% now, maybe you're wrong on this figure, but a significant number, over 51% of the appointees to the Naval Academy were political.
Now they're almost all, even if they're political, they're all competitive on civil service basis because so many people want to go.
And when...
Well, at Annapolis, did you have any drawings toward it?
Were you guided towards something like oceanography, for example?
Did you assume to be a line officer?
No, I had always wanted to be in nuclear physics for some weird reason.
I can't explain exactly why.
And it was even before the H-bomb, or the A-bomb, rather, that I'd wanted to be there.
I'd always wanted to do graduate work.
And I think that's a function of the parentage I had, that there was a tremendous drive to get advanced degree.
My father had a PhD and a DDS.
The whole family was sort of education-happy, if you know what I mean, in that generation.
I'd wanted to be in nuclear physics.
When I graduated from the Naval Academy, I thought I wanted to be in flight training.

My wife did not want me to be in flight training, so I went through indoctrination of flight training, then went to sea and never had a second thought about going into aviation, never had any desire to go into submarines and wanted to be a destroyer, a tin can driver.
Right after the war, I put in to go to postgraduate school at MIT to get a
a doctor's degree in nuclear physics.
I was turned down on the grounds I hadn't had enough sea duty.
And each time I got eligible to be a principal and was selected to be a principal for postgraduate education, I would end up by having a job where nobody would release me.
I finally got into nuclear physics through the back door by a weird rule in the Navy that doesn't permit ensigns, that's the lowest rank, to serve on shore duty.
A young officer who was an ensign was serving at Los Alamos, New Mexico in the nuclear physics program.
They found out what the law was, so they ordered me.
And I was then a Lieutenant JG to his replacement.
And by the time I got there, he had already been promoted.
But anyhow, I went out there.
I was going to go to postgraduate school that year, so I went to Los Alamos, New Mexico instead.
I stayed there under, I think my orders were classified.
My classified orders told me I was to work on the bomb project.
My unclassified orders said I was to go to the University of New Mexico in an NROTC program.
I went and worked at Los Alamos, New Mexico as a, first a staff assistant, and then, I can't remember the exact title, but then a staff member.

I was never in uniform, but I was working on the initiator for the hydrogen weapon at that time, and had always wanted to go to school, and was still putting in for school at that particular point in life.
I stayed there, I believe, two years, and then
went to sea for a year in order to get the adequate necessary sea time.
And then I went to Naval Postgraduate System and then went to MIT, but did not complete a PhD.
I was only allowed two years there, and it took a minimum of four at that time.
So I ended up with a master's degree in nuclear physics.
Came back, went through various phases of sea duty, then was assigned in my shore job, my next shore job, was assigned to be

the Polaris reentry body systems officer because of my nuclear physics background, because of my assignment in Los Alamos, and because Admiral Rickover wouldn't permit an assignment of a nuclear submarine if they weren't too scarce to take the job.

So although not being submarine qualified, my job there was Polaris reentry body systems design officer at Lockheed in California, and also the atomic energy representative on the Polaris program in circa 1958.
I did that job, then I went to

War college and I went to see in command of a destroyer and while I was in command of a destroyer The assistant secretary of the Navy for research and development was attempting to fill a billet for special assistant here in Washington and Again, Admiral Rickover had not enough qualified officers to fill his requirements at sea So very few of them were allowed to go ashore So again, I got involved in what I would consider submarine business, even though I was not a qualified submariner

And during the meantime, during all this history, I'd also been interviewed by Admiral Rickover, and I'd been rejected by the admiral for command of the Bainbridge or executive officer of the Long Beach.
I'm not sure which job.
I had always wanted to do that.
In 1958, I'd put a letter in requesting command of the first nuclear power destroyer circa 1960, which was about the time I was interviewed by Admiral Rickover.
I then was accepted by the assistant secretary
the Navy to be his special assistant.
I'm not sure exactly why he accepted me.
He asked me if I'd had any tour duty in Washington.
I said no.
He asked me what I thought about the Bureau of Ordinance, and I said it ought to be reorganized.
He asked me what I thought about the Bureau of Ships, and I said I thought it should be abolished or combined.
Maybe it was I was a maverick.
I don't know for sure.
I then went back to the Brownson.
My memory here is a little bit hazy.
It was circa April 63.
The thresher was lost right off of where I was with my ship, but my ship was on its way to the Navy yard.

So I came down and reported to the assistant secretary on temporary duty, even though I was not to be permanently assigned to him until June or July, and started taking over the secretarial responsibility for oceanography, if you will, by accident.
And I suppose that it's a fair statement that since April of 63,
My primary job ashore in the Navy has, in fact, been oceanography.
And I've been closely associated from that day forward.
I have a couple of follow-up questions I should like to ask right here.
First of all, with which assistant secretary were you attached?
The first assistant secretary, Dr. Wakeman.
I've actually served for every assistant secretary for R&D because of the timing involved and because of Dr. Frosch stayed so long.
He was still here when I came back from Vietnam.
Dr. Wakeland was the first assistant secretary.
I believe he served five years less five days.
He was the one who was instrumental in setting up the Interagency Committee on Oceanography.
It was he who went to Mr. Eisenhower, who was then president of the United States, and got the president interested in oceanography.
It was he who encouraged the Navy to participate with the other agencies and with the academic institutions to significantly increase their budgets in oceanography.
And I think he could be properly really referred to as almost the founder of major oceanographic programs in the federal government.
That would be my assessment.
Perhaps it's biased from the fact I worked for him.
But I think without him, we certainly wouldn't be where we were today in spite of the National Academy report and in spite of other things.
But I think he was the driving force in the bureaucracy that was interested.
Even though he was responsible for all of Navy research and development, including weapon systems, he put a significant amount of time.
He almost was the kind of individual who put a 40-hour work week on four or five separate subjects.
And I was his specialist assistant for oceanography, submarines, Polaris, and a few other side things.
And I put at least 60 hours a week in oceanography.
And it was a very interesting time in oceanography because there was no competition in a bureaucratic sense.
The Navy felt, under Wakeman's leadership, that so much had to be done that they were not concerned who did it.
The Navy felt that it needed to be significantly expanded.
When I say in the Navy, I'm speaking of Jim Wakeman, because the Navy has so many problems, it never knows which problem is on top other than the one at the critical time.
Wakeman left, and Dr. Morse came.
And I served the full two years with Dr. Morse when he was assistant secretary.
And I served one year plus
maybe six months with Dr. Frosch, who relieved Dr. Morse.
Then I went to sea in Vietnam.
I came back, had a tour, continued tour at sea in Newport, Rhode Island, made admiral, spent about six or seven months as admiral's bill at Norfolk.
And Dr. Frosch asked me to come back and relieve Admiral Behrens as oceanographer, if Admiral Behrens left.
And when that happened, I kept both jobs till about June.
And I've been here full time since June of 70,
I guess it is.
And there's been some controversy, which I'm sure you're aware of, in the interim and so forth.
Exactly what did you do in Vietnam?
I need this with a specific oceanography.
I did no specific oceanography in Vietnam except looking for several downed aircraft.
The job I had in Vietnam was commanding officer of the last battleship, the New Jersey, which was activated.
It was a

joke, but it was covered, and I can't ever find the piece of paper, but it was covered in the ships of oceanography as the world's largest oceanographic ship, and I think there were several jokes about how quiet it was because the machinery was 1,500 men pulling on ropes, but we had a full suit of oceanographic equipment on board except a submersible.
We put a submersible on board and it was taken off because nobody wanted us to have it.
We had handheld sonars and we had salvage and survival gear, but we were so contained on the

demilitarized DMZ, that's the demilitarized zone, by the Army and the Marine Corps that they were so imbued with a capability of this piece of artillery that I never got a chance to play games, as I would call it, by playing with oceanography.

And then you, after this tour of duty in Vietnam, then you come back and... No, then I go to Newport, Rhode Island, where I was chief of staff to the destroyer force, which was an administrative job, plus
trying to get them to do things.
I was interested in doing a lot of work in anti-submarine warfare, trying to get the Navy back in oceanography from a combatant side of the viewpoint.
And then when I made admiral, I became head of the training command of the Navy east of the Mississippi.
The Navy has two training commands, east and west of Mississippi.
So I had charge of all the Navy schoolhouses and so forth east of Mississippi.
and that gave me some chance to exercise oceanography, but not really greatly.
Would you characterize your developing interest in oceanography primarily through anti-submarine warfare, since you've always been a destroyer man?

No, I would characterize it by falling into it with the thresher going down and being put in it under the leadership of Wakeman, and I think anybody that's been subject to Mr. Wakeman's leadership sort of gets part of his enthusiasm wiped off on him, and I think the challenge of the
of oceanography, once you see it, is certainly clear to me.
Now, let's be sure you and I understand what we mean by oceanography.
In the Navy, oceanography is very clearly defined.
It's not anywhere else, but it surely is in the Navy, and I even wrote the definition of that and finally got the Secretary of the Navy to sign it, and it's very broad in the Navy.
It covers so much that when the Secretary first looked at it, he said, you're writing a charter for the Chief of Naval Operations.
We'll have to change a few words.
What it basically is is
all that science, technology, operations, engineering that is necessary to develop and exploit the world's oceans for military and other national needs except for weapon systems design.
But then, on the other hand, it includes how does the weapon system operate in the environment and how do you use the weapon system if it's an underwater weapon system, for example.
So it's pretty inclusive, even though
In dollars, it isn't advertised as much more than $200 million.
You probably have $2 billion underneath of the tip of that iceberg in anti-submarine warfare surveillance and things like that.
A question that's anticipating things in the future we're speaking of, really.
But the charge has been that the Navy has become less and less interested in pure science in terms of R&D and more and more interested in specific sciences, that is, sciences which would...
aid the Navy in military affairs only.
That's called the Mansfield Amendment.
That's right, exactly what that's called.
I think that when you say the Navy, I think you always have to be a little bit careful.
I live in the Navy, so the Navy is like any other organization.
There are at least 12 different voices in the Navy.
I think that what they mean is a true statement, except in oceanography.
An interesting thing about oceanography is no one has ever argued the Mansfield Amendment in oceanography.
Many of the people working in the Office of Naval Research
in order to feel that their program is very solid, have changed titles and changed emphasis to make the amount of work they do more specific towards the acoustical side or the physical side.
I think that this is a normal thing to occur when you take history and you go back far enough.
The Navy was the major supporter of ocean science, basic science, basic research.
Today, I forget the exact figures.
We could look them up, but I think the Navy is just like about 25% of the national support, and the National Science Foundation is probably more like 40 or 45.
NOAA, if you count the Sea Grant, is probably another 15, and then the states are probably another 10, and there's probably another 2% from industry or catch can.
I think it is very clear, and I've had this argued and discussed, that at the policy level, the Navy has never exercised the Mansfield Amendment
or felt it necessary in oceanography.
It has in computer technology, electronics, nuclear physics, et cetera.
And I think the reason that they don't in oceanography is probably the similarity of everything one does in the ocean.
And I would characterize that as the single environment that I've run into in my lifetime that everything you do
is a function of the environment.
By that I mean, if you go into outer space, it's a step function of, let's be hypothetical about it, it's a step function of one atmosphere on Earth and zero atmospheres in space.
If you go in the ocean, what is it, one atmosphere per 32 feet of salt water?

Something like that, which means that if you go down to 1,000 feet, it doesn't make a damn bit of difference whether you're tying up a Christmas tree or you're putting a surveillance station or you're listening to a listening device or you're putting a pipeline.
The difficulty of doing the job is measured by the difficulty of the environment as opposed to the difficulty of the job.
Many people will argue this, but I think those that have been at sea and tried to go down deep will concede that picking up pieces of the thresher is no different than picking up a manganese nodule.

The only difference is if you ever get out of science and get into practical utilization, then you will specify a different system for picking up nodules than picking up pieces of pipe, for example, but
the prototype or the research and development or the science necessary to do it are identical.
The science doesn't know.
I think a classic example is using the BTs, the temperature versus depth, for anti-submarine warfare and using it for location of tuna fish.
And we have, as I'm sure you're aware, very quietly made arrangements with many of the US tuna fishing industries to jointly work with us.
We have to be careful about this because
they are perhaps as proprietary or as...
They don't want other people to know what they're doing, just like an oil company doesn't, and I think even more so perhaps than the Navy.
Now, is it fair to say then that in terms of reference to the Mansfield Amendment, that you feel as if Navy ought to be broad spread in terms of experimentation with oceanography?
Absolutely.
The only problem is that
If you have only $30 million and you have $90 million worth of work to do, you have to put your $30 million towards the highest priority projects.
And you can argue that there's no such thing as a high priority project in basic science, but that isn't quite true in oceanography.
We do have weapon systems and ships and things already built that don't know how to be used in the ocean.
They can be basically used, but you don't know how to use them to their maximum efficiency.
We have weapon systems that we still could make them maybe 20, 30, 40, 50% more effective if we understood more about the physical processes in the ocean and so forth.
Of course, the maps we use, the depth maps, which we use on occasion for navigational purposes,
The more accurate we can make them, the better they are for navigational purposes.
And of course, everybody in the ocean, whether you be a scientist, an engineer, or a developer, has got to have a map.
And if you're working off the bottom, you better know what the bottom looks like.
So the similarity here is so identical.
I think an interesting thing that I was talking to the new undersecretary about just on the trip down to Mississippi,

was something that I don't think that he recognized, and that is that interestingly enough in scientific oceanography, and by that I mean university oceanography, that the measurements made by the scientists are fed in real time directly to the computer the Navy runs at Fleet Numerical in Monterey and fed to the fleet because we are so lacking in knowledge of the ocean that we are in fact using basic science as an operational tool, which is not true in electronics, physics, mathematics, or
the other things that the Office of Naval Research, for example, on the scientific side is involved in.

And I don't know how to articulate this except that we don't yet have the mathematical model of the ocean, so we're still in the sort of wandering stage where we can derive beneficial results from an operational standpoint by just knowing what the temperature versus depth or temperature versus salinity or the estimated acoustical range or the sea state is, that we haven't gotten ourselves to a point where
We don't have to rely on the basic science.

And I have programs which, if you were looking at the measurement side of the program, you wouldn't be able to distinguish whether it was being done by Texas A&M or whether it was being done by the Bureau of Ordnance on the Mark Wasit weapon system.
And one would be funded out of operational and maintenance money, which the Navy is very complicated with seven different congressional appropriations.
The other one would be funded out of basic research money.
And I think this has given us an advantage in oceanography, which many people call a disadvantage.
But I think it's an advantage because we can even use warships to collect oceanographic information and data.
And we're hoping to be able to computerize enough things and standardize.
And again, to standardize not in an academic sense because academic people, when you use the word standard, get frightened or don't want to do it for one reason or another.
But if you could standardize just
instrumentation and calibration for routine types of measurements that all the scientists use and also the operators use, I think we'd be a lot better off.

We're having problems in that arena, but I think the technology of computer technology and transmission via satellite and communications in general are without any question at a point in time where you can do this if you had the money to set it up.
Now, speaking of standardizing, which we are in a different sort of way,

is I think most people in, for lack of a better word, political oceanography, most people agree it was you who first standardized the oceanographic office here, a sense of bringing all aspects of naval oceanography into one central office.
Would you agree with that?
Well, let me say that I'm the one who first, not the one who first tried it, I probably was the one who was in a better position to get it started.
I think Tex Treadwell was trying, I think everybody, Art Maxwell was trying, I think,

The difference was I was sitting in the secretary's office, and the secretary was very interested in not standardizing but consolidating, I think is a better word, trying to get a critical mass without destroying everything.
At the same time, you always can get a bureaucrat's interest by saying, I'm going to consolidate because he sees savings.
We were not trying to make savings.
We were trying to get more efficient programs.
I think we have failed to consolidate the program.
I think we're making another attempt right now to consolidate it in Mississippi, and I think it'll be five years.
I think you will have finished your research project long before you can answer the question, is that attempt to consolidate going to be successful?
The one up here was only maybe 25% or 30% successful.
All right, now, what I should like for you to do is to describe the way it operated before you took it over and what you had in mind
how you wished for it to operate when you were through.

Well, I'll have to go back to 1963 when I knew nothing at all about oceanography and walked into an office and suddenly discovered that we had lost a nuclear submarine the first time we'd ever lost one.
We'd lost it with all hands on board, and I couldn't understand it.
I couldn't understand why here we had a submarine in an operational area with a surface ship in complete communications with it, right with it, and didn't know where it went down exactly.
Naval officers seem to think they know where they are at sea, and they don't have the foggiest damn idea as far as accuracy is concerned.
By accuracy, I mean accuracy to be able to use your sensors.
So all of a sudden here I have, I'm given the responsibility for the secretary, and of course this is an anomaly in the Navy.
Why would we have a discipline in the Navy that in effect was managed from the office of the secretary of the Navy?
That is different.
To my knowledge, I could be wrong about that, but no intense bureaucratic management on any other field has been done by the Secretary, not even nuclear power.
That was done by Admiral Rickover himself and outside the Secretary's office.
He had some assistance initially, but the Office of Naval Research is legally managed by the Secretary, but not really.
The Chief of Naval Research almost runs his program unhindered.
The missile programs got secretarial attention because they needed it to get started, but then they were pretty much managed outside.
The other program that got secretarial attention, I guess perhaps most notorious, was the Polaris program, and that was needed because the Navy had never done it.
But then again, you had Admiral Rayburn and Levering Smith and Dr. Teller who made the contributions that really did the program.
I think oceanography was never really accepted as...
in the Navy as something that was absolutely necessary.

Hydrography was accepted and the Naval Oceanographic Office, I believe, Ray Hagen can give you all of the actual searched history of what it went through, but it went through basically charting and it wasn't until
I don't really consider it was until World War II when people really got in and called things oceanography.
They'll say 1930, 31, 33, but really that's not true.
Really, it was World War II, the submarine threat, the inability to understand why they'd see them sometimes and wouldn't other times.
And that put Woods whole in the business.
And I think there's an interesting thing that's never been true in another discipline, with the possible exception of the Manhattan Project when it first started.
But in oceanography, it's continued.
Here I walk into a field which I'm new.
I mean, I had nuclear physics and mathematics, so from a novice scientific standpoint, I'm not a novice.
But from a oceanography standpoint, I'm a novice.
And I suddenly discover that the contributors
to the location of the Thresher are not the operational Navy or not sort of engineering Navy.
They're mostly basic research people.
They're the academic people plus the Naval Research Laboratory.
I mean, there are operations out there, but the people we are talking about.
And then I think the thing that fascinated me was then to discover the next crisis that I personally faced, and I don't remember exactly the year, but circa 1966, we lost the
The Air Force lost the hydrogen bomb off of Palomares.
And I can honestly tell you that we received calls from every major US academic institution instantaneously.
I didn't have to ask them for help.
They were on my phone.
Hey, Ed, what can we do to help?
That's so unusual in an operational world.
And operational by that, I don't necessarily
confine myself to military, but even industrial world.
Here you have an academic group that feels obliged to come forward, and not only feels obliged, but have better capability, in a sense, than the full operational Navy.
And this was true in the Thresher case.
Now, from the Thresher to the Palomares bomb, we'd started to move rather rapidly from an engineering viewpoint, and we had started to put significant more money into
basic research, and we had started a major program for shipbuilding to build egg oars.
And I think it's also very interesting to recognize that up until about four years ago, the Navy provided the only federally funded ships for the oceanographic programs in the universities.
And the only reason we're not doing it now is not the Mansfield Amendment, but it's a very simple problem.
The Navy lost so many ships

stricken from the register, the cost of shipbuilding has gone up so much that the Navy's requirements are so severe, they just don't have the damn money to buy the ships they need like aircraft carriers, so there's nothing left over for things that you and I feel are important, but the man who's trying to fight today's battles hasn't got the money to put on the future, which I call the future of the country being the ability to exploit the ocean.
But then I'm very parochial in that view, and I think most of us are who've worked in the program.
Well, the last ship we built was the one that went to Texas, A&M.
Last one funded by the Navy.
And don't forget, these ships were not funded by Office of Naval Research.
A lot of people think they were.
These ships are funded by the Operational Navy, the same dollars that buy the combatant submarines and the combatant aircraft carriers and the combatant destroyers.
And I fought this battle, and I lose in the dollar.
I don't lose in principle, but I lose in the fact that when you get through today's world, you haven't the dollar left over.
And I think it's bad, but then I don't know how I'd feel if I were the chief of naval operations with all the problems he's got on the shoulders.
